NOTE: The game's sound is bugged due to Compatibility issues. I have provided the FIX at the bottom of this review and I do hope it helps.TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Max Payne is the first title to the highly acclaimed Max Payne franchise. Originally developed by Remedy Games back in 2001, it has then received multiple awards for its story telling, gameplay and graphics from critics and gamers alike.Max Payne is a third-person action game where the player takes the role of a hard-boiled, no non-sense New York City cop named, you guessed it, Max Payne, who is on a mission to avenge the death of his wife and infant daughter in the hands of vagrants who were high on a street drug named Valkyr. He sets of to find the people responsible for the production and distribution of Valkyr who he holds responsible for his family's death.PROS:+ Story: - At first glance the story seems to be a cliché cop drama, and, yes I would agree, HOWEVER, it's the presentation, execution and overall delivery of the story that makes the original Max Payne a gem on action drama story telling.+ Gameplay: - This was the fist game to incorporate the now popular 'Bullet Time' effect where time basically slows down allowing the player more accuracy for combat while at the same time adding theatrical spice to the gunplay. This might not be relevant to the current generation of gamers but back in 2001, it was one of the game's highest selling points.+ Voice Acting: - Fantastic voice acting from the cast specially on the character of Max Payne with his dark humour and gritty personality.+ Atmospheric: - The graphics for its time is top notch and delivers a very dark and depressing world that reflects the slowly changing personality of Max. From the dank and cold city streets to the surreal nightmarish realm of Max's dreams, the game stands tall on atmosphere and immersion.CONS:- Bugged Sound for Windows Vista/7/possibly 8: - Being 13 years old, the game does suffer from compatibility issues. Gameplay wise, it functions well enough but users will encounter a bug that renders no audio in the game. (Note: LINK TO THE FIX IS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS REVIEW)- Replayability: - Linear story is FINE, its a good way to tell a narrative story in a directed pace but Linearity does sacrifice replayability at degree because after finishing the story there is little reason to play it through a second time around. Like a good action movie, it's best to be played again after some time has passed.- Facial Animation: - Max has a permanent facial expression where the devs tried to give him a gritty look but they just ended up making him look smug and/or constipated expression through out the game. Good thing the Comic Book cut sences are there to save the day.CONCLUSION:Max Payne is a GREAT GAME that started a great franchise. It brought us the mainstream Bullet Time effect that most action shooter gamers has come to incorporate and embrace as a core game mechanic. It showed us a perfect blend of action and storytelling in one single game without sacrificing gameplay and mechanics.It is a fast paced brutal 3rd person shooter that fans of the genre should not miss out on. Sale or full price, this game is worth the money and worth the time.SOUND FIXMax Payne Sound Fix by DarkjeThe2nd:http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=848215YouTube Instructions on how to install and use the Fix by MrMario2011:

												They were all dead. The final gunshot was an exclamation mark on everything that had led to this point. I released my finger from the trigger, and it was over. Story Max Payne is your everyday New York cop. That is until one day, his loving wife and newborn daughter are murdered by three drug addicts. The drug addicts were using the "V" drug, a hostile and dangerous drug, which is getting bigger and bigger in New York City. After the dead of his wife and daughter, Max becomes an undercover DEA agent, working on the "V" drug case. Three years later, the city of New York finds itself in the biggest snow storm in history, and the "V" drug rempant the city. Max gets a tip from another DEA agent. An old friend of Max, knows something about this "V" drug. Finally meeting each other, his old friend Alex Balder is shot right before Max's eyes. Now, Max is framed for the murder of his friend, and is more than determined to break the "V" case. Gameplay Max Payne is known for it's great bullet time, and its smooth third person action gameplay. The basic gameplay is actually pretty easy to master. There are three parts in the game, every part has around seven to nine chapters. In every high detailed chapter you mostly walk through the chapter, killing every enemy in your path. Even though this sounds easy, Max Payne is a fairly difficult game. Which will take the average gamer around 9 hours to complete the main story. Max Payne is iconic for it's amazing bullet time, your stamina meter slowly fills up, which will allow you to dive or run in slow motion, easily picking off enemies. Conclusion The first Max Payne in this amazing trilogy is a joy to play. Some people might back away from it because of its outdated graphics. The amazing and complicated story is a very fun ride, while the great gameplay really takes the cake. For any fans of great third person gameplay with an amazing story, here you have a great game for your collection. 8.5/10

												The biggest challenge in this game is to make it playable in Windows 10! - "Windows 10" out of 10 :PTips:1. DO NOT use the Anti-aliasing (AA) setting from within the game settings (game launcher)! Turn it off completely! If you want to use Anti-aliasing (AA) in Max Payne, then force it via your graphics card driver, like, for example, in the nVIDIA Control Panel - this trick fixed the crash that I always had after the first cutscene!2. DO NOT play the game in a 16:9 resolution (like, for example, 1920 X 1080), play it in another resolution (like, for example, 1680 X 1050; btw, this is a 16:10 resolution) - this fixed my "fullscreen problem"!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												This review is essentially a reminder....to myself.Most of the time when I write a review, it's not just preserving a memory, it's putting a time-stamp on it.Eventually I'll play through Max Payne again, or maybe I'll play through its sequels. When that time comes around, I want to have something to compare and contrast with. This is also so that I don't fall into making the same discussions, or focus on material that I've already covered in a previous review.It's my personal Hell.Speaking of Hell, Max Payne sure went through some♥♥♥♥♥♥didn't he? He was practically touching the American Dream, but then it all fell apart in a New York Minute. His blood-soaked tale of revenge is about as good as 3rd-person shooter storylines need to be. The plot is great, the characters are memorable, and the writing is artsy...well the good kinda artsy. It's enough to make you care, enough to make you imagine, but not so into itself that it comes off as pretentious trash. Max Payne is a bit more cultured than you'd expect from a homage to John Woo films and Noir comics.But let's focus on the game itself. Max Payne 1 is a classic. Despite being released nearly 14 years ago, it still holds up and is great fun today (grab the widescreen fix). These days we tend to demand more from our videogames. When we pay however much it is that we're willing to, we expect our videogame to do a lot. The third-person shooter is no longer allowed to just be about shooting people, aliens, robots, mutants, or all of the above. There has to be stealth-elements, a vehicle, some turrets, and a segment where you walk slowly and wait for the exposition to finish. Max Payne 1 is almost quaint by comparison. There's some platforming, a moment where you don't have a single gun, and stupid pet tricks (shooting switches & trip-wires). Otherwise all you're going to do be doing is shooting people. Walk into a room, bad guys appear, and you shoot them. All of the encounters are scripted, and if your eye is quick enough you can sometimes see thugs appear out of thin air. Shockingly, this standardized approach manages to maintain its high level of quality entertainment, for the 7+ hours a first-playthrough is likely to take.Where similar games fall to the depths of mediocrity and banality, Max Payne rises above. This is precisely because it gets the primary form of interaction (shooting people) absolutely perfect. Let's start with the bullet. Your mission is to put bullets into enemies while trying to keep them out of Max Payne. There's none of that hit-scan nonsense in this game. While you can't always see the bullets as they travel, you know where they're coming from, and where they're going. These bullets travel at the same speed, cut through friend and foe alike(always a plus when bad guys accidentally shoot each other), always leave an impact. This isn't something you're liable to notice when you start the game, but over time you will acquire a new-found appreciation for bullets and the mechanics that revolve around them.The most important strategy is to keep moving. Enemies tend to aim for your head/chest, so you're most vulnerable when standing still or getting up from a dodge. Gun-battles are short and to the point; either you die in a couple seconds, or the bad guys die in 10-15 seconds. Making shots count is important, especially if you're using the slow-motion dodge. Bullet-time can also be very effective when used properly. It's not free, and you'll get yourself killed trying to play Neo, but it's good for those times where you need a moment or two to figure things out, even during a gun-fight. Otherwise, your best strategy is liable to be F5/F9ing your way to success (though it's not so effective on the hardest difficulty). The most interesting aspect of Max Payne is that once you think you've finally grasped how the game works, it's about to end. This is where you move onto the next difficulty, and see if you've really learned anything. When a game focuses almost entirely on one element, you will find yourself focusing on that same element as well. With every firefight you learn something new, you calculate how many shots you can make with each gun while dodging, you mull over every situation and what you could do to not only survive it, but to own it. The controls, mechanics, and everything else that makes the genre work is done in spectacular fashion.I'd write more, but I think you should play this game and see for yourself. Although I would be shocked if you haven't played it already.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Let me tell you why this game is so darn good. And why it has dated oh so well.Max Payne, I don't know where to start, I love this trilogy so much (Even though I love two first games much more)Max Payne centers around...well..Max freaking Payne, a tragic character who's family has been murdered in cold blood. Max decides to go for a revenge, and one good revenge at that.Sounds cliche? Well, things are not as they might seem, the game knows it, heck, Max knows it, the game is self-aware while still taking itself seriously, this strange blend of humor and drama makes the game date better. Max himself is a very likeable chap, you'll hear his voice a lot, and he monologues quite often.This helps the player to understand Payne more, his personality, his feeling at that very moment. He tends to speak in a very monotone voice.Story is being told through gameplay, comic artworks and cut-scenes, cut-scenes are not used very often, they don't tell the story most of the time actually, they're there only to show you the place and some enemies coming to get you. The game rarely takes the controls away from you. You get to also play Max's nightmares, and nightmares they are indeed, they are most likely one of the creepiest levels you encounter in non-horror game. And yes, this indeed is quite genius. This makes us think about Max more, trying to make up our thoughts about the visuals before us.Game has amazing voice acting, every character is voiced perfectly, the only problem some people might have is strange acting which can be seen in comics. They look silly most of the time; Sam Lake really knows how to make the weirdest faces. But then again it is most likely intentional, I wouldn't be surprised, the game really doesn't take itself too seriously, well, it does, but at the same time it laughs at itself, at its cliches etc. Not to mention Max's model has this smirk throughout the whole game, Max is most likely thinking like this:He knows how his quest silly sounds, he knows how cliche it sounds, he knows his quest is impossible, that self awareness is what makes the game date oh-so well.Soundtrack is top-notch as well; the main theme is truly heaven to ears as it pretty much presents Max Payne's personality.Gameplay is extremely fun and addicting, the main mechanics this game explores are bullet time and shoot dodge. They work well and smoothly, you will not find a franchise which does this better. Even Matrix games got it wrong. The game IS challenging when you start, you'll need to learn how to use these mechanics to your own good. Spamming shoot dodge won't get you anywhere; you can't spam it, if your bullet time runs out Max cannot use it anymore. So you better thing before using it.Max Payne can heal himself using painkillers; he can have up to eight painkillers which he can use whenever he wants. They encourage the player to explore for them. Game has 3 difficulties, only one being avaible at the beginning, that being the easiest one, which is still not quite easy. Luckily the game has quick saves, if that's too "cheap" for you then play on the hardest difficulty which limits your saves. Even with quick save though the game is no cake walk, game will spam a lot of enemies at you, but the game is fair, it is not unfair.Level design offers the player to explore a lot of areas, there are many weapons painkillers to be found which make Max's journey through madness much easier. The game never feels repetive, even though you do just shoot guys in the face, it's most likely the levels, they're done so well.At the end, Max Payne not only has dated well, but feels quite refreshing, this is no cover shooter, it's quite the opposite, this is not about hiding, this is about going into the open, shooting everyone up, quick thinking. The game can be completed around ten hours, depends on your skill level. But the fun doesn't have to stop there, there is a "New York Minute" mode for the speed runners who wish to run through the game as quickly as possible, it has a timer on every level, you score more and more time the more enemies you kill. The mod community offers quite a lot of content to enjoy, complete game changers, minor changes. And it's really easy to install them.Guys at Remedy, I love you. Thank you.10/10 I am biased? Maybe, probably, most likely. Do I care? Nope.

												First off, I'd like to say that I won't talk about graphics and game physics, because obiviously they're pretty bad compared to games nowdays, I'll review this game as if I played it back then when it came out(Which unfortunately, I didn't).Pros:+Excellent level design - there's no set objective you need to follow, no markers or pointers that lead you exactly to where you need to go, you gotta figure out all of that on your own with hints that the level designers put it in to give you some kind of direction. I often find myself in a serious need for painkillers(the health pickups), and it feels so good to find some in a secret place. You don't really see these kind of games anymore.+High quality voice acting(especially the narration and cutscenes, which I'll talk about later) - nothing much to say here, just that the first time I heard the narration, it was so good that I thought it was recoreded about  2-3 years ago.+The gameplay - I've never played the game before untill now, so I didn't know what to excpect from a game this old, and I have to say that I genuinely enjoy the gameplay. Of course, the animations are a bit clanky, but it still feels good, the weapon variety, the shooting, the bullet time, everything.+The comic book-ish cutscenes - I really love the way the story is told, instead of  advanced animations with crazy effects, each cutscene is a comic book "page", beautifully drawn and narrated.+The story - I haven't finished the game yet(I don't think I'm even close, only 5 hours in), but so far the story is quite good, right at the beginning the game throws at you some powerful and sad scenes. My expectations are high, I'll update this section when I finish the game.Cons:-Illogical enemy spawnings - the enemy spawnings are pretty weird in the game, most of them are activated by you reaching a certain point, but sometimes after you clear an area, and later need to backtrack, enemies spawn from no-where(of course not in front of your eyes), no doors openings or anything.-Bugged sounds, but it can be fixed anyway.Overall, I can easily recommend this game to anyone, don't be afraid of the old age, it plays perfectly fine, and anyone can really enjoy it.

												Nearly ten year ago the snowy rain fell on Hull like all the angels in heaven had decided to colloquially urinate at the same time. And so opened this innovative action adventure for me: I had a weekend to kill, it was snowing outside, and I had no heating. I didn't want the intellectually intensity of a strategy game, nor did I want to frenetic multitasking of a RTS. With a blanket on my legs, I sat down and completed this game in 10 hours without even a toilet break. And the first thing I did? Began again. After a toilet break.Max Payne pitches perfect progressive difficulty. Action games shouldn't - in my busy world - kill you more than three times at the same point more than three times. You shouldn't be slugging through a game with a face as pained as Payne's permanently constipated expression. Instead you should be smiling appreciatively at just how awesome it feels to burst horizontally through a door (in slow motion) and expertly twisting through your hips as you innerringly shoot three baddies with your John Woo pistols before time jolts back into the present and all three baddies fall down at the same time. Whump.This is not a serious game, but it is seriously evocative. The weapons, even now, feel powerful. I can remember a scene where a baddie hideing behind an apartment door unfortunately proclaims that he intends to shoot you as you come in. He doesn't, but you should, expect to leap towards him while simultaneously opening said door while unleashing a full shotgun blast to his chest that lifts him several feet in the air. You can almost hear Chuck, I mean Max, saying, "not today bozo."These scenes occur tirelessly throughout the game. Face an impossible situation. Engage bullet time (copied from the Matrix). Shoot all enemies. Read film noir comics.While the game itself is not so serious, what should be a series consideration is the known (and ongoing) compatibility issues with steam. Unfortunately the download can open fail to name the weapons file correctly which can result in the game simply not starting. While I managed to get it work (on occasion) you cannot expect Steam to help you out on this one. Much better to buy on amazon.Fortunately the game gleefully leads you on a deeply humorous (if a little silly) adventure once you have got the thing working. The dialogue between the baddies is priceless. Not to mention the subplot of the Lords and Ladies TV series - "My Lord! My Lady! My Lord!" - which goes on for about twenty minutes if you halt your carnage to watch the many analogue TV sets scattered throughout the game. Take this game for what it is - a romping film-noir - and you'll find an outstandingly crafted adventure that is also a piece of gaming history.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												Max Payne is an undercover detective wanting nothing else but revenge on those who ordered the hit on his wife and killed her and their newborn baby girl. Unfortunately for him, he's been burned and framed for the murder of his best friend, a DEA agent... His rage will be unleashed on New York City criminals while evading the police. What secrets will he uncover?Don't look at the minutes passed in Max Payne here on Steam, I happen to own the retail version. And also an italian version offered by a magazine when I was on vacations back then.So, you may bet, I loved the plot of the game. You're going from surprise to surprise and the noir ambiance is really showing Max's state of mind. Everything is done by night or underground or in dirty buildings. Even some side characters are well-written like Mona Sax, though you should play Max Payne 2 for more secrets about her. Eeer, what? Yeah, yeah, I like Mona. But I prefer the Mona of Max Payne 2 than Max Payne. Besides, you find alliances with people you would have never thought...The gameplay is simple: you shoot, you cover yourself, you shoot, you take painkillers to ease your pain and you use your bullet time feature to slow down time to avoid bullets and to kill more enemies. Anyway, I can't say that there is really more in Max Payne apart some puzzles (well, mainly to find your way but not the puzzles like you see in casual games). You have also a lot of weapons, interesting anyway to see Max carry so much of them. From shotgun to sniper rifle with grenade launchers, don't ask how he does. But the best is perhaps the nightmare sequence, that is separating each act.The graphics, while looking a little old today, are also very very good. The only problem I have is the fact that Max is having always the same smiling face. I mean, this is weird at the end. But really, each level is well builded and creepy in its own: from Ragnarock to the subway, passing by the Aesir Corporation so futuristic and by the docks.The soundtrack is also quite good. The main track is quite sad.But the best also with Max Payne, is that the story is told as a comic, with excellent voice actors. It's allowing the story to be darker and also to have subtitles.In other words, Max Payne was an excellent title, with an excellent plot and an excellent gameplay (the bullet feature was really helpful). It's not a wonder that it got turned into a trilogy. If you like action, you have to play Max Payne. Never regretted it back then... I should replay it on Steam too....

Posted: December 2, 2013
												TL; DR version: classic game, great story, PC = definitive version, <3One of my favorite games of all time!This isn't remastered in any way, this is the original PC version, so if you're playing it for the first time... this is a 2001 title! If you're here feeling nostalgic, skip reading reviews and just buy it :) If you haven't played Max Payne previously, please keep its age in mind when judging it for the first time.Though the graphics may not, the story, however, will always stand the test of time. Your wife and daughter are murdered within the first ten minutes, which is the basis of the mystery you must now unravel. Meanwhile, outside, the worst blizzard in years envelops New York City. The atmosphere matches Max's desperation, breathing life into otherwise usual settings like rooftops, or the docks, as you mow down foes in winter coats huddling around a trashcan fire. There isn't a dull moment in the game, whether Max is fighting armies of baddies, interacting with memorable villains (and allies) or losing himself in his own nightmares. The story gets an A+ in my book and an A+++ when compared to the trash passed off as game plots nowadays.The dialogue can be both fantastic and cheesy. Fantastically cheesy? Whatever you think of it, it is fitting to Max Payne's comic book style. There are cutscenes, but more often there are panels with speech bubbles and illustrations. I'm not sure if this was a budget or style decision, but it quickly became the series' trademark. There are lines, both funny and serious, which my friends and I quote to this day ("As in... you cry a lot?"). The shooting mechanics are fine. At the very least it has aged MUCH more gracefully than other old shooters. You don't have to aim precisely, just point in an enemy's general direction and shoot. It's not realistic. You can snipe people with dual submachine guns from across a rooftop, and carry 10 guns, 5 Molotov cocktails, 5 grenades and a grenade launcher all at once. You get a great arsenal by the way, and new weapons are steadily introduced throughout. Ammo is abundant. Painkillers are plentiful. I truly believe Max Payne was designed in a way to let you enjoy its story without getting stuck on this or that.I've also played Max Payne on several platforms: first on PS2, then original Xbox and finally PC. I play it every few years. PC is the definitive version. In addition to not having to dust off your questionable old system, which is stuffed in a closet somewhere (or at least in my case it is), it runs smoothest on PC, and there are little things you will notice (for example, the cool, comic book font used in the PC version was converted to a generic font in the console versions).It's worth the $9.99 Steam is asking, and it's on sale all the darn time so there's no reason not to revisit Noir York City, as Max calls it.Also note: there's a slight compatibility issue, and the audio won't work with Windows 7 initially. Check the workshop for a simple sound patch that takes moments to install and works flawlessly. Just follow the instructions exactly and you're good to go! Happy gaming!

Posted: March 31, 2016
"To make any kind of sense of it, I need to go back three years. Back to the night the pain started."While Max remembers what happened 3 years before we need to go back 15 years. It was in 2001 that Remedy released an action-pack video game that was the first utilising the slow-mo we got to like so much after Matrix came out. I remember it was not long after the first benchmark software, 3DMark 99 was released - one of the graphics tests included the lobby scene from the Matrix recreated spectacularly thanks to the Max Payne engine."He was trying to buy more sand for his hourglass. I wasn't selling any."That's right. Max goes after the entire underworld of New York as some junkies kill his wife and baby girl. The game is pretty linear - we go from one area to the next. Everything is pretty straightforward but while making progress the action is almost constant and it is very easy to die unless we regularly turn on the slow-mo effect. Making things slower around us allows for more precision-shooting, too. I like how Max uses painkillers to make the pain go away - not health packs but regular painkillers."A bomb went off, turning snow into liquid gold."The game aged a lot but still looks pretty cool. At the time Remedy's software was revolutionary in every which way. The accompanying music is a classic one - the game's theme was later on used in its sequels and became one of the signature elements of the franchise. "I was in a graphic novel. Funny as hell, it was the most horrible thing I could think of."There are dozens of cutscenes between the various stages but these all appear in the form of comic book pages. The narrator, Max, is actually played by the guy who wrote the game's screenplay, Sam Lake. We follow Max's internal monologues - his struggle with New York's evil and at the same time with his memories; the memory of losing his loved ones, something so painful that eventually set him on this dangerous path he can never leave."You piece together a jigsaw and the final picture is you finishing that same puzzle, a mad green-eyed killer standing behind you. An urban legend come true."There you have it: a classic 3rd person shooter that still matters. A game that has all the ingredients to give birth to an excellent action flick: Italian-American mobsters from New York, amazing dialogues / monologues and all this touched by a little - if not too much - film noir.I do not think there are many brands out there whose sequels became really good. If you like trying out classic games this is a must have for you especially since almost everybody who appreciates the modern technology graphics have - probably - already played the 3rd and last episode. You'll probably have a sound issue once the game starts up for the first time but thanks to the many guides available on Steam this can be solved immediately.PS: Steer away from the film adaptation released in 2008. It is the epitome of how bad video game adaptations can turn out.

My Personal Score: 3/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]Issues: has sound problems on Windows Vista and onwards. Fix and instructions on the PCGW page.Max Payne is one of those classic games that's really hard to forget because of the unique experience that it delivers. The cinematic gameplay, the gritty story, the noir-inspired aestethics - the game has a timeless quality to it that you rarely find in old titles. There's something about playing as a rogue cop who guns his way through crazy mobsters and corrupt government agents that I can't quite put my finger on which makes it so memorable. Maybe its Max's inner monologues about his sense of right and wrong. Perhaps it's the difficult gameplay and the "shoot first or get shot" attitude of the combat which really brings out the rush in the player. Whatever it is, there's no denying that Max Payne is still fun to play, years after its release and still holds up pretty well on all aspects.You play as the titular Max Payne, an appropriately named cop turned undercover DEA agent who lost his wife and daughter to drug-crazed addicts. The events of the game starts three years after his family died, at a time when Max is deep inside the Punchinello crime family, one of New York's biggest mafia organizations and a major distributor in the drug trade. On a snowy night, he recieves a call from one of his partners telling him to meet up at a train station and from there starts the ball rolling into the world of crime and corruption.Now, why in the world would you want to spend both your $$$ and time on this really old game? First of all, it's literally a John Woo action flick in video game form. The game features Bullet Time, slow-mo mechanics, and chaotic gunplay that Remedy, the developers, have admitted to having been inspired by the acclaimed director's movies. If you want to play a difficult action game without the constant hand-holding and the hassles of modern game mechanics, then this game is for you. Second, it has a mature noir story that's full of twists and turns. The game shows Max as an anti-hero, a man with nothing to lose who will go to great lengths to bring the people who killed his family to justice. He spends a night in New York getting tangled with the city's most ruthless individuals who plays each other for their own ends. An interesting detail with the game is how involved the world around Max Payne is. TV and radio shows report about the people of New York's overwhelming support for Max's vendetta against the mafia. The police are constantly on his tail as they try to stop him from causing further damage. As Max moves up the food chain, so does word of his presence. Small details here and there but it improves the immersion of the player in the story in a huge way. To top it all off, story segments and cutscenes are presented like a graphic novel starring the people who made the game. A tight budget forced Remedy to be as creative as possible and made the game stand out as a result. Sam Lake, head writer for Remedy Entertainment acts as the face and body of Max Payne with James McCaffrey serving as the memorable monotome voice.How about downsides? Well, as stated above, there are issues with the sound on modern operating systems which can easily be fixed. Other than that, I haven't experienced any performance issue or game-breaking bugs. There's also the fact that this is an old game, meaning that your tolerance will be tested if you're accustomed to modern titles. No health regen, no cover, an easy mode that kills Max in 2 hits - It's going to take a very patient player to finish the game.And there you have it.

Max PayneI don't know about angels, but it's fear that gives men wingsGeneral OverviewThe story of a broken man with nothing to loseSpanning the period of three years between 1998 and 2001, Max Payne is a former New York City Police Department homicide detective whose wife Michelle and six-month-old daughter Rose were brutally murdered in a home invasion connected with the investigation of a new street drug known as Valkyr. In response, Max joined the Drug Enforcement Administration as a secret agent and went undercover in the Mafia. Eventually, framed for the murder of his NYPD and DEA partner Alex Balder, and with his identity exposed, Max becomes a fugitive wanted by the Mafia and the police alike while waging his personal war on crime. Eventually, he discovers and seemingly destroys a powerful conspiracy behind all these events.My Own ViewsIts' hard to belive that Max Payne 1 is going to be 16 years old this year. Even though its now dated against MP2 and MP3 its still a superb game to go back and play. I urge anyone who has not played Max Payne who likes story driven shooters, play this game now.I have been a Max Payne fan from day 1, yet I refuse to watch the movie. (Lets face it most game to movie films end in disaster)The story telling in all Max Payne games is fantastic. The dark, gritty Neo-Noir style combined with Max's inner monolouge througout the game is superb. James McCaffrey does a superb job with the voice of Max, making Max Payne a very quotable and believable character.One of the first games to get "Bullet time" right and build's on it and makes it better with each title that follows. Also one of the first games that I remember that made the gun's feel powerful. For example with the shotgun, very loud on the sound and just a touch of screen shake on every shot made it feel powerful.Freerider-DaveThey were all dead. The final gunshot was an exclamation mark on everything that had led to this point. I released my finger from the trigger, and it was over

A story of revenge and conspiracy.	Max Payne is a third-person shooter released back in 2001. It was the first video game to feature bullet-time (slow motion gameplay). The gameplay is inspired by John Woo action movies. There's a lot of shooting while leaping, jumping and running in slow motion. Bullet time turns you into a badass but that's not all.The game gives you a wide arsenal of weapons: Bats, pistols, shotguns, grenades, a sniper rifle, an assault rifle and uzis. You can of course dual wield pistols and uzis and don't worry about having to pick between dual pistols or an assault rifle. You can carry the entire arsenal with you at all times. Slow motion dual wielding renegade cop with no thoughts of his own safety. You are death incarnate.Max Payne is a neo-noir thriller. The game uses comic book panels with voice overs to tell you the story. The story itself is presented to you through the eyes of our hero, Max Payne. He is narrating throughout the game.I can't really tell you much about the story without spoiling it. The front cover of the game should give you all the information you need: "New York. Fugitive Undercover Cop. Nothing To Lose."Max Payne was a big hit back when it released. Why? A dark neo-noir story combined with a very unique bullet time gameplay.It took me only 7 hours to beat the game but it's worth every single penny. Just trust me. The gameplay still holds up.

Posted: August 10, 2016
												Compatibility: No issues getting the game to boot on Windows 7 x64 (didn't even need to use compatibility mode).An options menu (similar to Skyrim) opens on boot and widescreen is available and works perfectly.There are some sound issues, mainly missing sounds for the cutscenes. These are resolved by a patch that takes 2 seconds to install.Story:Having played Max Payne 2 prior to this game I would say that this game's story is slightly stronger (grittier and perhaps a bit more personal). The story is propelled mainly through graphic novel panels. This works in the game's favor since the animated cutscenes aren't all that good-looking, with the character's faces seemingly lacking the ability to display any sort of emotion. However, the panels serve as an outlet for a constant barrage of metaphors provided by Max and these can get slightly tiresome.Gameplay: This is another strong point and the game certainly holds up to today's standards. The bullet time and shootdodge mechanics are fun and well-developed but the game is still enjoyable without using them. The difficulty level is much (MUCH) higher than Max Payne 2 and enemies sometimes seem to be able to one-shot you with shotguns even from afar. Good aim and strong nerves and required since a missed shot can be devastating when several enemies come rushing at you at once.  Even experienced players will struggle but frequently quicksaving will save you from the worst headaches. Summary:An unusually good story coupled with fun, intense and challenging gameplay makes this game well worth the 9,99€, and a steal at 2,49€ (steam sale).

IntroductionI have so many good memories from this game. Not from the specific one, but its sequel but that's the reason i know the series anyways. I am lucky that someone gave me the fall of max payne on PS as a gift, which was a significant part of my childhood. I recently bought this one and finished it for the first time. The fact that i have finished the sequel numerous times while knowing absolutely nothing about the original felt awkward. Well, it's about time i wrote a review.Story(No Spoilers)The plot follows Max Payne, a NYPD cop in the '90s, who was living the "American Dream" before his wife and child were murdered. Three years later,he is working undercover in a drug case, which is connected to the death of his family, when he is framed for his partner's death. Now he has to work alone to uncover the truth.Game TimeIt takes about 8 hours to completeIn detailTo begin with, it's a classic third person action ***(-adventure)*** shooter, with a great storyline and interesting action sequences, considering the year it was made.Pros+ Mainstream story but with a very interesting plot, but unfortunately, it seems that it's a small part of the game+ Great Soundtrack+ Graphic novels replace cinematic cutscenes, but not entirely, since there are still some.+ Bullet time+ Shootouts are too many to handle (dayum)Cons- Almost the entire game consists of shooting, shooting and shooting except:- The prologues of each part which are not only kind of pointless but can also become really frustrating.- ***Concerning the gameplay, there was no serious effort on map creation since they usually become boring, and simple. Not to mention the fact that they sometimes cover more than a chapter. Comparing them to the sequel's, they are not good, and deprive the of its potential of being consider an adventure game. Someone can easily assume that, at some points, it is like a hack 'n slash. game***- Also, i was disapointed by the small variety of weapons. Commiting a genocide with berettas, deagle and occasionaly an M4 can get really boring. Additionally, the ammount of bullets it takes to bring someone down (excluding headshots) is ridiculous.- Last but not least, the ability to save the game whenever you like makes the game less challenging, since this function can be abused, but no one, since the experience is ruined.Concluding, i recommend grabbing the game only on sale (usually ~75%) since i dont think it's worth full price.7.5 / 10.01. Dont touch it even if it's on the house [0-3 / 10].2. If you are bored of every other game [3-5 / 10]. 3. Grab it whenever it's on sale (or pay the full price if you are wealthy enough) [6-8] 4. Must Have [9-10 / 10]

He was trying to buy more sand for his hour glass. I wasn't selling any.Max, Max, Max.......Where did it all go so wrong? You had the American Dream and now look at you. The dream lies dead on the ground and you releasing your finger from the trigger. From "Golden Boy" to a wanted man, no angel could have fallen so far. This one is very high on my list of all time favorites. Even though there have been sequels, the original is the best as far as I am concerned. An early adopter of "bullet time" and pulled it off with more than a little panache. Like any rogue *insert profession here*, there must be painkillers involved. Think House with a bigger grudge, dipping into every stash he finds. Medkits are too bulky anyway, pills can be tucked into a jacket pocket. And guns, so many guns. Or should I use a grenade launcher. Would that be overkill? Better to be safe than sorry. A big draw for me was the art style of this game. It was like finding a diamond in the rough; the lack of polish, the roughness was what made it better than any of the subsequent games. It is dark, dreary, lonesome and this game conveys how gritty Noir York City is when you are on the wrong side of a badge. Cut scenes are set up in still panels, giving it a Grendel or Crow anti-hero comic book feel. "My whole life was just frames, words hanging in the air like bubbles. I was in a graphic novel. Funny as hell, it was the most horrible thing I could think of."Some of the mechanics aren't great, but you have to take the bad with the good. Opening cupboards and closets consists of running into it with enough force that it just pops open. Jumping in this is a bit of a chore. But if you manage it properly, there are a few Easter eggs to be found. And there have been occasions when I bullet time'd against a wall or onto the subway tracks.For the money, there might be other games to be had. But none of them will have the desperate need to go on, rather than safely log out and crawl into a nice warm bed with that loved one that Max can never have again. It's the little extras in the game that keep me playing. There's always a few seconds to spare after a fire fight to catch up on some TV or your newspaper comic strip after fighting your way free from captivity.The verdict my Lords and Ladies?The story is compelling, the style is dark, your fortunes are bleak, you have nothing to lose. You won't find Max, because the Address? UNKNOWN!

Posted: January 30, 2016
												This is without a doubt one of the greatest games of all time. Max Payne 1 is a third person action thriller video game that was developed by Remedy Entertainment and published by Gathering of Developers in July 2001. You play as Max, who is a NYPD detective who comes home one day to find that his family has been murdered. He then attempts to avenge the murder of his family. This game has a very gritty neo-noir style and it also uses a graphics novel to tell the story in full detail. This game comes with incredible atmosphere that is very depressing and goes along perfectly with the ambient soundtracks. This is also one of the first games to feature the bullet time affect that was popularised by the matrix. I fully reccomend playing this game even today, this is just one of those games that never gets old.If I was to pick a game that I had the greatest experience playing, it would be this one. I remember being around 9 years old, having a computer that could barely run this game. I bought this game for just £2 at a used games store without knowing anything about this game. I got home and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥I was suprised. This game just seemed to be utterly perfect to me and before I knew it I found myself getting deeper and deeper into what some gamers call "the zone" I have had this with other games, but never like I did with this one. Everything other than this game started to fade away as I was playing it in a dark room. it got so strong that it was almost like this game became my entire reality and it was the only thing that existed in the universe. It was so strange, but it was probably one of the greatest experiences of my life.

												Max Payne... The beginning of a franchase too amazing to be missed.With a script blended with a way so darn cool naration that made the story way too awesome for its time, this game set the flag for a new awesome style of detective/police drama concept in video games.The gameplay and action is fantastic (and pretty damn difficult at some points) with OMGWTF♥♥♥♥YEAH shooting gameplay and a slo-mo bullettime that makes it even more eygasmic. The effects and graphics are neat for its time.What's also interesting about this game is that it is different in some levels from the other Max Payne games out there at the moment.There's some unique humorous and other mind♥♥♥♥ing moments (whick can't be mentioned due to spoilers) that don't exist in the other games in teh same way they are introduced here.Also the character's face is a whole different face model. Although Timothy Gibbs (Max Payne 2) and James McCaffrey (Max Payne 3) had quite some face structural similarities the face model of the main character in Max Payne 1 is based on Sam Lake in honor of his work as he was the writer of the actual original story.It is very important to mention that the naration and voice acting is absolutelly AfreakinMAZING. With James McCaffrey giving his voice through the entire franchise (so far) Max is a character unique beyond comparison.Please note that there are compatibility issues with the late OSs (just like most old games do) after installing.here you will have everything resolved: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1858303Absolutelly recommended. If you are a fan of the genre I urge you to start this franchise.And if you haven't played the first Max Payne but you did play any of the other two, unless you have issues with old game graphics, you must try this no matter what.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												It doesn't look very good today, and we've seen the central mechanic copied a thousand times since, but this is a classic of action gaming that's proven very influential over the years, for better or worse. Even if it hasn't aged the best, the copious helping of noir style and dead-serious melodrama mixed with weird humour make this one still worthwhile, and I recommend running through it as part of a full trilogy run. It comes from a simpler time where shooters could just be about shooting everyone, with no vehicle sections, no hacking minigames, no rpg elements, no sandbox elements, no moral choices, no collectibles, no quicktime events, no... well, you get the idea. It can seem like a relic today, but I appreciate the simplicity and devotion to doing one thing and doing it well. Coupled with one of my favourite video game protagonists, and this one remains a fond memory even when played today.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												If you've played Max Payne before, you already know what made it such a great game back in 2001. If you haven't played it yet, I highly recommend you pick it up here or for an old console at a used games shop. If you do decide to purchase it on Steam there's a few things you should know:Max Payne is a classic and, like a lot of classics, it did not age well. It’s been 15 years since Max Payne was first released and things have gotten a lot nicer for us in that time. If you’re expecting HD graphics and flawless gameplay you will be disappointed, instead I would suggest that you pick up Max Payne 3 for a much more updated take on the series or Remedy’s awesome thriller Alan Wake. If you’re willing to do a bit of work for a great game experience, you should be happy with your purchase. To get up and running as quickly as possible, you can follow this guide by Citizen Cook which will make the game playable for Windows 10 users. If you’re more comfortable tinkering with game files there are plenty of mods and unofficial fixes that can be found online to improve your experience. Each system can encounter different bugs so I suggest playing the game for a few minutes and searching out fixes for any bugs you find.Despite having a good time overall with the PC version of the game there were a few bugs still present that I wasn’t able to fix on my system. I’d like to list them here with my workarounds so you can see for yourself any deal-breaking bugs that you’re likely to encounter:Graphics settings - As with a lot of old games, the higher you set your graphics, the more likely it is you’ll run into trouble. Increasing the resolution to fit your monitor will stretch the image while decreasing it will leave you with black bars. This guide by Sleeper aims to fix that. I could not get the game to start unless anti-aliasing was disabled.Collisions - You may come across some issues with your character or the enemy AI getting stuck on stairs or small obstacles typically jumping will fix the problem but sometimes you may have to roll backward and jump over the obstacle completely to move forward. You may also find that sometimes you get stuck in walls and are unable to back away from them. Moving forward will usually release you once you get to the next room or you can try rolling backward as soon as you realize you’re stuck. I wouldn’t consider it a game breaking problem but it does affect your ability to “shoot dodge.” You’ll complete this playthrough with a lot more combat while running - you’ll frequently dodge from behind a corner only to become stuck on that corner. This bug also made it difficult to jump over gaps as your character seems to want to stick to the floor at ledges, but these were really only a problem for me during the dream sequences.Dream sequences - Yes, they’re in the game. No, they aren’t any more fun than the last time you played them. (Sorry, Remedy. Loved the break in action to explore Max’s psyche, hated the weird platforming exercise.) If you have difficulty jumping between the blood trails due to the collisions glitch, try running and jumping sideways. Diving sideways seems to clear the gap easily but make sure you direct the following roll so that you don’t accidentally roll off the path. If you find yourself stuck on a wall you can jump over the nearest doorway and you’ll be free when you land on the ground, for this reason it’s best to stay in the middle of the hall during the extended hallway sequences.Cutscenes - In several of the cutscenes, the characters may get stuck on a small obstacle they were intended to move over. As soon as you notice a character get stuck, pause and resume the game to free them. In one particular instance (While chasing Vinnie Gognitti down a spiral staircase.) the actors in the cutscene were able to open fire and kill the player character before the cutscene was over. To keep Max alive I had to move the player character backwards without being able to see him until the camera returned to normal.I fully enjoyed Max Payne back in 2001 and I’m glad I had the opportunity to sit down and play it again on my PC today, even if the experience was quite different. Quicksaving is going to be your best friend and the initial setup may not be as easy as you’re used to, but it was well worth it to me to be able to return to New York for some good old fashioned revenge.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												At this point, it's difficult to tell the completely-serious-ridiculousness of the 90s from actual satire. Released in 2001, Max Payne exists in a time so close to the height of 90s bravado that it hasn't quite dissipated yet, but we might finally be ready to start talking about how silly it all was. For a fifteen-year-old Playstation port, the game itself has held up surprisingly well, perhaps even gaining a bit more accessibility in the move to the PC. The interface is clean and intuitive, the transition between shooting gobs of interchangeable mooks and the fastforwardable/rewindable cutscenes is smooth, and the bullet time mechanic is game-changingly useful without entirely dominating play. Other than the platforming elements - that have no business in this game in the first place - Max Payne is still a joy to play. Even when being encouraged to abuse the quick save function to solve cheap instant-death scenarios, it doesn't stop being fun. But what makes the game memorable are the little touches: the casual nature of the conversations between enemies before you burst into a room, the sensible placement of guns and painkillers, the way Max looks towards and mentions cutscene-inducing items but lets the player activate them on his or her timescale. Where Max Payne shows its age is in the flat, pasted on faces of its character models. Everyone is made out of sharp-edged boxes and Max himself is caught in a perpetual squint that never fails to decimate his dramatic creditability. This weakness only highlights the brilliance of the graphic novel styled cutscenes though, as they can be relied upon for any moment that wants to hold on to its pathos. And that's what Max Payne is made of: a handful of brilliant choices that leave its equal amount of flaws mostly ignorable.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I remember this game when it came out in early 2000-something. Specifically, I remember the PC game magazine reviews of the time loved the "bullet time" effect, letting you slo-mo gunfight like a scene from The Matrix. The only exposure I got first-hand was playing a demo on a store computer at a Costco electronics section. However, the thing that stuck out most to me at the time was Max Payne's goofy-looking grimace during cutscenes. And having played the whole thing now? The grimaces are REALLY goofy looking. Obviously the graphics have aged but that only serves to underscore how wonky these pasted on faces seem when the rest of the character model is more pixelated. Overall, I didn't really like it too much. The gunplay mechanics are rudimentary. There's no cover really, besides standing behind boxes or around corners. And this doesn't really help that much because enemies have lightning reflexes. When you strafe out of cover they fire IMMEDIATELY. The only way to avoid getting shot is to use some bullet-time every time you come out of cover. There is no stealth. Even melee kills aren't "silent" because no enemy can be killed in one hit, even from behind, and this triggers the alert. The lack of any stealth counts as a big negative for me. Furthermore, enemies react instantaneously when they spot you. They go from having a casual conversation to firing at you immediately. There's no surprise or shock when you run around a corner. Seems like a small thing but it really made me feel like this game lacks polish.Speaking of lack of polish, other little things just pile on to bring down the experience as a whole. When you stand in front of cabinets and open them the doors swing outward but get jammed on your character model. You have to step back to allow the doors to open all the way.Story-wise, I enjoyed the comic-panel style of the cutscenes and the noir-esque monologues. Speaking of which, it annoys me that Max's in-game model looks very different from the Max Payne in the cutscenes. As far as depth and richness, this game is basically an interactive shoot 'em up action movie with all the flaws that entails. The ending doesn't really bring a lot of closure but honestly I didn't care, for better or worse.

												Amazing game! Every 90's kid who had access to a computer growing up more than likely played Max Payne, or pined for the game because it turned you, the player, into Neo from the Matrix (this game came out around the same time the Matrix trilogy was being released in theaters, so for all of us young teenagers and gamers at the time, Max Payne was the ♥♥♥♥ :D).** GETTING THE GAME TO WORK **There are guides for running bat files, etc.However, I found a simpler solution that worked for me (eliminates the need to manually run a bat file from the root directory or a shortcut everytime--my way allows me to launch from library). I don't know if it's a universal fix, so if this doesn't work for you, then I apologize -- just google guides for 'Max Payne Windows 10 fix'; you will get a resolution if mine won't help.Here's how I got it to run on Windows 10:1. ------> go to ../steamapps/common/Max Payne/        ----> find "maxpayne.exe"          ---> right click on "maxpayne.exe"            --> click on "compatibility" pane (no pun intended ;])              -> look for the area that says "compatibility mode"                > Enable 'Run this program in compatibility mode for:' and set the option to either Windows 95 or Windows 98 in                      the drop down menu (find which one works for you).2. ----> Go to: https://thirteenag.github.io/wfp#sec2       ---> Select "Download" from the first widget box. This is for Max Payne 1. The second widget box is for MP2.        --> Follow the instructions from the website and extract the contents of the zip into the root Max Payne dir.          -> Launch the launcher -- the zip file we extracted in the previous step contains the Direct X 8 library necessary to play the game and scale the graphics to newer aspect ratios.            > Put in your 16:9 or 16:10 settings, upgrade the graphics options, etc. and press play!3.-> Whenever you see a cutscene in game, or one of those comic-esque interludes pops up, press the "E" key. It will start the cutscene over but play it with sound this time.      > If this doesn't work, just google the sound fix.10/10

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Max Payne really is quite the video game. It is one of those video games that makes us question what a video game truly is. Almost all the cutscenes are done in a graphic novel style literally going from one page to the next after the charecters have spoken. It is very interesting and unique to the point where I wanted to play just to get to the next scene sort of like how I would want to play MGS games just to get to the next scene. However unlike MGS the gameplay is extremely unique. It is a third person shooter that places Max in the middle of the screen with a crosshair in the very center of the screen. Most people who play this game rave about how fun it is to use the bullet time effect to take out enemies. I agree that it is extremely fun and sometimes difficult to do. You use quick saves in the game which you NEED TO USE unless you are a god at the game then you will not be getting through that many levels without dying. Ofcourse there is an autosave feature but it is pathetic how often it is used. With quicksaves you will find yourself saving before a fight then going into the fight and most likely dying in which you will rethink everything like where you aimed, how you entered the area or what gun you used.Let me just put it this way. I was up late exausted playing this game just desperatley wanting to get to the next scene.I think the only bad things about the game (gameplay wise) really are the underpowered weapons or not knowing where to go or what to do at times.Now the bad things about the game in general that are not really related to the gameplay is how Max just all of a sudden becomes a mass murderer after his family is killed. Max never talks about how hard it is to shoot and kill people just to get to the person responsible for the murder. There is also quite a lot of blood and very sexual things in the game but I think that is to be expected when the game is advertised as a Noir story.Overall this game is fantastic and if you are not bothered by anything that I have mentioned in the last two paragraphs you are crazy not to be playing this game as soon as humanly possible (Unless you are one of those unfortunate enough to have a computer that will not start this game up due to the direct X 8 requirment)UPDATE: After updating my driviers to catylyst 14.12 for my AMD 6670 graphics card and running the game in compatibility mode Windows 98/ME I have got the game to work on my Windows 7 64 bit computer. I had to use the audio fix afterwards and I was running the game fine.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Quick-save happy action game squarely of the old school variety. At the time of release there was just nothing else like Max Payne. The Matrix was fresh in the minds of the masses. System Shock 2, Half-Life, Deus Ex, had all been released. PC gaming couldn't get any better. Or so we thought.Controls may seem wonky to youngins raised on the buttery smooth engines of late. Mechanics may seem unpolished if you're used to a skill ceiling in reach of "everyone". Max Payne can both challenge and frustrate you. Gameplay-as-story was new and had only been woven succesfully into a handful of titles. It stands as a great example of a "pure" game, hitting all the highs the medium has to offer. It hasn't aged quite as gracefully as other classics, but strap into a comfy chair with at least a few hours to spare, turn the lights down and your sound up and prepare to enjoy an excellent affair of cinematic gaming in the dark underworld of a frozen New York City.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Quick-save happy action game squarely of the old school variety. At the time of release there was just nothing else like Max Payne. The Matrix was fresh in the minds of the masses. System Shock 2, Half-Life, Deus Ex, had all been released. PC gaming couldn't get any better. Or so we thought.Controls may seem wonky to youngins raised on the buttery smooth engines of late. Mechanics may seem unpolished if you're used to a skill ceiling in reach of "everyone". Max Payne can both challenge and frustrate you. Gameplay-as-story was new and had only been woven succesfully into a handful of titles. It stands as a great example of a "pure" game, hitting all the highs the medium has to offer. It hasn't aged quite as gracefully as other classics, but strap into a comfy chair with at least a few hours to spare, turn the lights down and your sound up and prepare to enjoy an excellent affair of cinematic gaming in the dark underworld of a frozen New York City.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2013
												I finally played through this game. I remember playing the demo years ago when it was new, but I thought the theme was too dark and didn't play it.  I figured it would be easier to play now, but the beginning of the game is as dark and creepy as ever, although it does provide you with strong motivation. The game makes liberal use of bullet-time from The Matrix.  Heck, it even steals the hotel lobby scene right out of the movie, which is a blast to play.  The effect is done masterfully.  At first, it seems like this may make the game too easy, but before long,  you realize you'll need it to survive.  There is no health regen, only a limited supply of pain pills you have to hunt for.  The game was released in 2001, so the graphics look dated now, but you can tell they were very good for the time.  The game supports widescreen resolutions, but it stretches out the picture.  You'll be better off picking a 4:3 resolution with the same height as your monitor.  If you have sound problems, setup the game with Alchemy (SoundBlaster only) or look for a user patch.  The game clocks in at "only 10 hours", which was short for back then. It makes you wonder if this started the trend towards shorter, but more action packed games.All-in-all, a great game.  Better games may have been made since, but Max Payne raised the bar and left its mark.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												I completed Max Payne a couple of days ago. It was a really fantastic experience from the beginning to the end!Just over a decade ago a friend gave it to me as a gift on Retail CD for PC. I played it for a bit but never had a chance to complete it back then. Unfortunately the CD stopped being recognized and I gave up on it. But coincidentally 4 years ago I was gifted on Steam by another friend.This time I decided to play it again. I never had any issues running the game on my Windows 7 system. The only issue I had was the sound being messed up. There was no sound in some parts of the game and other sounds disappeared. It is a compatibility issue with the latest operating systems. But luckily this problem was easily fixed by a Max Payne: Sound Fix! patch that is found in the Steam Community Hub Guides tab. After that the game ran flawlessly!Anyway, the graphics aren't up to par with the latest computer technologies, but they are of a high standard and exceptional for its time. The story is compelling, if sometimes a little difficult to follow, and once you start playing it, you don't want to stop! You want to know what's around the next corner and where the story will turn next, it really does get you hooked! Level designs are varied and the gameplay is not repetitive. There are a total of 25 chapters in the game and each and every one of them is different so it constantly keeps you engaged. You can also manually save and not rely on checkpoint savings like some of the older PC titles. This is particularly important for a game like Max Payne where you'll come across difficult enemies. Enemies range from street thugs to military commandos. The first few stages of the game will present little problems for players, as enemies will rarely engage you and create life threatening situations. The latter stages of the game present much more complex situations, bombarding you with enemies in very close quarter areas. Enemies are pretty relentless throughout the game, so it's wise to sniff out painkillers and keep plenty in stock to top up any lost health and to also make sure to manually save each time you overcome difficult enemies or scenarios!You also have a variety of weapons to choose from. Whether a baseball bat, handguns, assault rifles, grenade launchers, snipers, etc. You have full control over the enemies. Not to mention that in every particular scenario of the game you'll find that you'll need to choose different weapons for different situations! You cannot rely solely on one weapon only, that's what I like about this game. In one situation you'll need to throw grenades and in another you'll be requiring to use the sniper to kill enemies that are shooting from far above you.Max Payne is also the first game to introduce bullet-time effects (like those seen in the Matrix). During a gun fight Max can slow down everything around him to allow him better aim and an edge over his enemies. You could instigate the bullet-time parts of the game over and over again and they would still be as awesome to watch as the first time.It's just great fun to let loose with any weapon and reap the benefits of destruction. Not everything is about killing, as some moments will call upon Max to solve mini puzzles, or even traverse hazardous routes in order to progress. Overall Max Payne is a fantastic third-person shooter, full of action and energy. The story is dark and backed by immersive film noir attributes. The graphics depict New York City in a stark fashion. The gameplay is highly entertaining and a complete bullet-fest from start to finish!

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												You all know why this game is good. Many of you feel a great deal of nostalgia towards this game. So did I.I'm writing this review to remind you that besides this game's many strong points like great story, awesome graphic novel style cutscenes, good soundtrack, spot-on voice acting, there are also flaws.First of all, Steam version is garbage. If you run Windows 7 or newer, expect some amount of tinkering to even make it run. And it's something that developers or the store itself could have fixed very easily.Second - this game is not really meant to run on widescreen resolutions. The hack I used caused the dot crosshair to become very small, making aiming harder, and also somewhat altered camera placement so Max's body often obstructed the line of sight.Third - there are sound problems, which again are fixable with the external tool.Fourth - forced vSync. You can kinda hack it off, but extremely high framerates cause some issues, which again will require you to use external tools to limit the framerate to 60 to fix them. Playing with vSync on causes aiming to feel very sloppy, almost vanilla Skyrim level bad.Fifth - this game is brutally, ridiculously hard. There is A LOT of instances where enemies kill you LITERALLY WITHIN A SECOND. Getting past those instances is possible either through dumb luck or through quickloading 10-15 times. Enemy placement is somewhat dickish, and they also will ambush you, including from areas you just cleared. There is a special place in hell for grenade throwing enemies, as grenades explode within 1 or 1,5 seconds after landing and will kill you instantly in most cases.Sixth - weapon spread and accuracy are pretty much constant with Max's stance and movement having no tangible effect on them. There is no recoil at all, and the fact than spread is very high with most weapons makes the combat more luck-based than skill-based.Because of all this I can't recommend this game, at least not the Steam version. If you have not played it and still want to, get it. It deserves to be played. Perhaps its flaws only serve to thicken the noir atmosphere it's going for. It may not look like much today, but it was a breakthrough back when it was released. Just try to get it elsewhere first.

												Don't let the inital lack of sound fool you (Google the sound patch for it and it'll all be fine), this game is timeless. Having just recently started getting into video game franchises, I decided to give Max Payne a try (it was bundled with Max Payne 2 for only a few bucks!). Boy, was it a good choice. Due to my being accustomed to third person shooters like Uncharted, it was definitely jarring going into the game and realising there's no cover and the enemies have no propensity for self-preservation. And Max is very easy to kill (meaning in the gameplay, not in the storyline). This made things extremely interesting and fast paced. The AI could be dumb a lot, but I mean AI wasn't what it was now. Nevertheless, these elements made for very actiony gameplay. Although the game is set in the 90s, the atmosphere, the vehicles and the dress of some of the characters made it all seem like a proper film noir. The storyline is intricate and very entertaining and the graphic novel scenes are very well-voiced (for the most part).And of course, I can't do this without mentioning bullet time. Springing forward or sideways in slow motion to take on your enemies is so satisfying. Best of all, the bullets are all rendered, even shot from your shotgun, meaning it's not just hitscan and you can see the bullets  land. It's really cool. All in all, the game is cheap and very much worth it, even after all these years. 9/10

 One of the most underrated third person shooters ever made Max Payne is a third person shooter that revolves around Max Payne, an ex-cop who arrives to find his wife and daughter killed by junkies, from there the story unfolds, I won't give anything major away, but it's a very gripping game. I really enjoy the noir feel to the game, the graphics look fairly good considering it's age, the face models do show their age, but if you can look past dated graphics, it's a great game, there are also nightmare sections which give a psychological feel to the game, my only complaint being, it has platforming, and can be a bit annoying after a while.         There's also a difficulty scaling system, so if you're killing goons left and right with no real problem, the game bumps up the difficulty, it can be quite annoying at points, but that's the only really thing I disliked about the game.The game also features a "Bullet Time." system, you dive through the air slowing down time allowing you to shoot at enemies, it's a cool system, and never feels overpowered.Pros: Decent graphics considering the date of release.         Gripping story.         Bullet Time. Cons: Difficulty scaling.          Annoying nightmare platforming.Also, as a side note, I suggest looking up the sound fix for the game. Otherwise it makes weird sounds when in bullet time.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Even though published already in 2001, Max Payne still keeps on rocking. Max Payne offers an interesting and dark twisted plot which keeps you quessing until you reach the very end of the game. As a side note, the developers of Max Payne had decided to create easter eggs and other interesting visual appearences, which combined with the awesome story the game has to offer leaves you willing to play the game through yet another and maybe the third time.Gameplaywise Max Payne is basically a run and shoot game with a very little variation between the firefight scenes you encounter. The range of usable weapons in the game is pretty small and the amount of bullets you will have to consume to kill the enemies is absolutely ridiculous. Also the enemies have a bad habit to come out of the blue or suddenly throw grenades which are almost impossible to evade within the given time. With that being said the gameplay of Max Payne is quite fast-paced and needs to be played with a great amount of concentration. Despite the negative sides of the gameplay, there is also something good to say about it. The level design of the game is pretty unique and really one of those things which arouses the original Max Payne-like feelings in the player while playing the game through. The voice acting in the game is great and the facial expressions the enemies as well as Max have on their faces are rather funny. Also the controllability of Max's moves is very well done and the fact that there is so much awesome mods made for Max Payne gives it some added value.Overall when you get used to playing Max Payne, it isn't that hard to beat on any level. I have played Max Payne through once before I owned it on Steam. After I got the Steam version, I made three more playthroughs, with every given difficulty option. And guess what? I just cannot regret the time spent playing on this obvious game. After the first (Steam version) playthrough I found myself enjoying outdated graphics, some visual appearences and the certain things in the actual gameplay the game has to offer. When you find your kung fu being strong enough this is your best bet. With no doubt you will not regret it!

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Remedy's first Woo/Matrix inspired, action packed, third-person shooter in the Payne franchise delivers on what you might expect yet is somewhat limited in scope compared to their future efforts. People might remember the Max Payne games as a moody homage to noire detective thrillers, interrupted by bouts of exaggerated slow motion action but the reality on both accounts is surprisingly different.The story (although creatively executed through comic book panels, expressive art, and some iconic musical themes) couldn't be more generic but that's OK because of the unique tone that remedy has struck and are now somewhat known for. From the outset it may look like a dire tale of a cop whom's family is murdered, framed for the death of a fellow DEA agent and on the run through an abandoned New York City (by way of that good old excuse, a dire blizzard) killing his way up a chain of endless wacky criminals and mob families to eventually discover a deeper conspiracy. Max Payne is remembered in part for its great story but the writing and structure themselves aren't particularly well executed, with far too many criminals, conspiracies, and betrayals for even Max's gravely narration to keep track of, and a fractured narrative structure that serves to confuse rather than contextualise the events of the story. Apart from some major Wikipedia plot points, if you asked me to tell you what happened in the first Max Payne I would draw a blank. The inherent character and tone that Remedy bring are what makes the story engaging. It manages to both take itself seriously and be incredibly self knowing, occasionally fourth wall breaking, and treading into pastiche territory upon occasion. There are some very funny in-game TV show's to watch and NPC conversions to overhear which break the tension of the story and combat, and give what is essentially an endless series of rooms to shoot though a sense of place within a larger world. The flavour of the story and the slow motion shooting mechanics and are't just the core of the experience, they are the experience.     Despite the bevy of weapons (including duel pistols, shotguns, Uzi's, rifles, and some more ridiculous♥♥♥♥♥♥later on!) the gameplay loop consists of shooting your way through endless empty subway stations, hotels, office complexes, and gang hideouts, slow-mo launching yourself into a room filled with enemies while clumsily contorting your body into odd poses as you attempt to leverage your limited time to exert the maximum amount of payne. It's clumsy and unrefined but undeniably fun. A modern interpretation would feature better animations for jumping over cover and other contextual actions but this is mainly of visual importance. Only some occasional unintuitive environmental puzzle design hinders your endless slaughter.The way the game is balanced is somewhat of a double edged sword. It's quite difficult and unforgiving (Max will perish in a few shots without downing a few dozen handfuls of delicious painkillers) to incentivize accuracy, the use of the slow-motion mechanic, and to make fights feel satisfying. The downside is that it prevented me from getting too creative with the tools they had given me. I ended up sticking to particular lines of sight and repeating consistently successful moves whilst fantasising about slow-mo launching myself down a spiral staircase or letting lose on dozens of enemies in the open, but I guess there are always cheats for that sort of thing. The levels are designed as a series of rooms with limited scripted events, it's all very simple (with only unlock-able difficulties and time trial modes offering replay value) and as such, can become repetitive although new weapons and drips of narrative context motivated me to continue despite this.The first Payne outing is about establishing a tone and a gameplay rhythm that would later be refined upon as well as showing off some impressive graphical fidelity (if you can ignore Muppet hands and Max's permanently constipated facial expression) and slow motion technological accomplishments that were impressive for the time and still hold up today. Max Payne 2 is the superior game in every way, making the first seem like more of a proof of concept or a tech demo with a smaller scope by comparison, but all the ingredients are here and they still make for a fun game.
